questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about Gorlin syndrome?
questions.solution:
NEVOID BASAL CELL CARCINOMA SYNDROME (NBCCS) (BASAL CELL NEVUS/GORLIN SYNDROME)

  • Autosomal dominant disorder
  • The development of multiple basal cell carcinomas,
  • Before 20 years (choice A)
  • Accompanied by various other tumors (especially medulloblastomas (choice B) and ovarian fibromas, odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms and soles, and certain developmental abnormalities.
  • NBCCS is one of a number of cancer syndromes associated with skin manifestations.
  • The gene associated with NBCCS is PTCH (choice D), a tumor suppressor gene that is the human homologue of the Drosophila developmental gene patched.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Gorlin syndrome is associated with medulloblastoma.

choices.text: Sun exposed sites are frequently affected

questions.text: Choose the INCORRECT statement about actinic keratosis?
questions.solution:
ACTINIC KERATOSIS (as the name implies) usually occurs in sun-damaged skin and exhibits hyperkeratosis.

  • Precancerous
  • Risk of maligancy ~ 8-20% of year (progress to Squamous cell carcinoma) (choice B)
  • Aggravating factor: chronic sun exposure (Choice B)
  • Roughly scaly plaque
  • Clinically cutaneous horn (choice D)
  • Microscopically:
    • Atypical keratinocytes in lower third of epidermis (dyskeratosi) (choice A)
    • Alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis
    • Sparing of cutaneous adnexa
    • Solar elastosis in dermis
  • Treatment: Liquid nitrogen, 5-HU, shave, curettage, toll like receptors

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a precancerous skin lesion caused by chronic sun exposure and UV radiation, primarily affecting sun-exposed areas of the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an elevated, flat topped lesion, usually greater than 5 mm across?
questions.solution:
A flat, raised skin lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Plaque is a flat topped raised lesion more than 1 cm.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the following case? (Clinical and microscopic image given below).
questions.solution:
Melanocytic Nevus

  • Benign, localized proliferations of nevus cells (a type of melanocyte)
  • Defined by the presence of nests/clusters
  • Clinically small, (usu. <5 mm), well-cicrcumscribed, symmetrical, evenly colored.
  • All over body, esp the trunk
  • "Aquired" and grow during childhood
  • Most common with light skin
  • Clinical: light brown macules/papules
  • Frequent BRAF(esp V600E) mutations
  • Types:
    1. Junctinal nevus - Nests of melanocytes at DEJ (dermoepidermal junction) only
    2. Compound nevus - Nests at DEJ in papillary dermis
    3. Intradermal nevus (IDN) - No junctional component (dermis only)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Melanocytic nevus is a benign, dome-shaped lesion that typically occurs on the face or neck. It is histologically characterized by nevus cells confined to the dermis, showing no atypia, and rarely requires intervention.

questions.text: A 29 years old male has small nodules on forehead and scalp since childhood. Clinical and microscopic images are given below. This patient harbours CYLD gene mutation. Which adnexal tumor from the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CYLINDROMA

  • An appendage tumor with ductal (apocrine or eccrine) differentiation
  • Location: Forehead and scalp
  • coalescence of nodules with time may produce a hat-like growth-hence the name TURBAN TUMOR.
  • Dominantly inherited lesions
  • Characteristic jigsaw histological pattern.
  • Associated with inactivating mutations in the tumor Suppressor gene CYLD
  • In addition to familial cylindromatosis, germline mutations in CYLD are associated with two other genetic syndromes marked by the occurrence of multiple adnexal tumors, multiple familial trichoepithelioma (a follicular tumor) and Brooke-Spiegler syndrome (associated with both trichoepithelioma and cylindroma).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A cylindroma is a rare, benign skin adnexal tumor derived from eccrine or apocrine sweat glands. It often presents on the scalp or face and may be solitary or multiple.

questions.text: Mycoses fungoides is also known as?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) spans a spectrum of lymphoproliferative disorders affecting the skin.

  • MYCOSIS FUNGOIDES: A lymphoma of skin-homing CD4+ T-helper cells that presents in the skin.
  • In most affected individuals, the disease remains localized to the skin for many years, but it may eventually evolve into a systemic lymphoma.

Histology:

  • Patch Stage:
    • Epidermotropism: Atypical lymphocytes infiltrate the epidermis.
    • Pautrier microabscesses: Clusters of malignant lymphocytes in the epidermis.
  • Plaque/Tumor Stages:
    • Dense dermal infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes.
    • Cerebriform nuclei in malignant T-cells

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Mycosis fungoides is a chronic cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with progressive skin lesions.

questions.text: Choose the correct diagnosis from the following clinical and histopathological features. This patient has an eyelid lesion since last one week.
questions.solution:
MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM: Skin disease produced by a Mollusc poxvirus, a virus specific to humans, present worldwide, and passed by direct skin to skin contact.

  • Young individuals and may even be congenital.
  • Small, firm, usually multiple nodules that, when fully developed, have central cores from which white keratinous material can be expressed.
  • Microscopic features:
    • The dermis is indented by a sharply delimited and lobulated mass of proliferating epithelium.
    • cytoplasm gradually is filled by a faintly granular eosinophilic inclusion that displaces the nucleus and enlarges the cells
    • MOLLUSCUM BODIES are formed of viral particles that are similar in size and mode of formation to the poxviruses.
    • Inflammation in the Surrounding dermis is intense, sometimes in the form of an abscessand sometimes in the form of a pleomorphic T-cell infiltrate that can simulate a lymphomatous/leukemic process

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Molluscum contagiosum shows Handerson Patterson bodies.

questions.text: Identify the bullous lesion on the basis of the given histopathological and direct immunofluorescence images.
questions.solution:
BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

  • Older individuals
  • Sites of involvement: the inner aspects of the thighs, flexor surfaces of the forearms, axillae, groin, and lower abdomen.
  • Oral lesions are present in 10% to 15% of affected individuals
  • Urticarial plaques and severe pruritus.

MORPHOLOGY

  • Tense bullae filled with clear fluid involving erythematous or normal-appearing skin.
  • The bullae are usually less than 2 cm in diameter but occasionally may reach 4 to 8 cm in diameter.
  • They do not rupture easily
  • The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, nonacantholytic blisters.
  • Early lesions show a superficial and sometimes deep perivascular infiltrate of lymphocytes and variable numbers of eosinophils, occasional neutrophils, superficial dermal edema, and basal cell layer vacuolization. Eosinophils are typically present directly beneath the epidermal basal cell layer. The vacuolated basal cell layer eventually lifts away, allowing space for a fluid-filled blister to form.

Direct immunofluorescence: Most antibody deposition occurs in a continuous linear pattern at the dermoepidermal junction.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Bullous pemphigoid (BP) is a chronic, autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by subepidermal blisters due to autoantibodies targeting the basement membrane.
